title: SA authorities confirm 3 dead in light plane crash | ABC NEWS
description: South Australia Police have confirmed that three men died when a light plane crashed near Goolwa South. Emergency services responded to the incident at Long Bay around 4:20 PM on Friday. The victims included the 57-year-old pilot from Morphett Vale, as well as an 18-year-old and a 19-year-old. The wreckage has been recovered and brought to shore. title: Trump deletes video depicting Obamas as monkeys | ABC NEWS
description: US President Donald Trump shared and then deleted a video on his Truth Social platform depicting Barack and Michelle Obama as monkeys. The video featured debunked conspiracy theories about the 2020 US election, which Trump claims was stolen. The White House had previously defended the offensive depiction as "an internet meme." description: British police have searched two homes linked to Peter Mandelson, the disgraced former UK ambassador to the US, as they investigate his ties to the late paedophile Jeffrey Epstein. title: Police designate 4yo Gus Lamont's disappearance a major crime | ABC NEWS
description: Police have classified the disappearance of four-year-old Gus Lamont from South Australia's Yunta region as a major crime. They have identified a suspect who lived at Oak Park station, where Gus was last seen. The boy's grandparents have hired lawyers and stated they have cooperated fully with the investigation. title: WA's Pilbara braces for intensifying tropical Cyclone Mitchell | ABC NEWS
description: Residents along Western Australia's Pilbara coast are preparing for Tropical Cyclone Mitchell, which intensified to Category One last night and is expected to strengthen further. "Watch and act" warnings have been issued, with potential wind gusts of up to 150 km/h and various storm and flood warnings in place. title: Trump faces backlash over racist video | ABC NEWS
description: US President Donald Trump shared, then deleted, a video depicting Barack and Michelle Obama as monkeys on his Truth Social platform, explains ABC's Americas editor John Lyons.  The video mainly included debunked conspiracy theories linked to the 2020 US election, which the president has falsely claimed was stolen from him.  The post was deleted despite the White House earlier defending the racist depiction of the former president and first lady as "an internet meme".
